handleHttpGet.description: Processes incoming HTTP GET requests, serving static files or executing R context scripts.
handleHttpGet.details: 1. Follows similar debug and routing logic as \code{handleHttpPost}.\cr 2. Additional static file handling: Serves files from `wwwroot` via \code{host_file()} if path exists.\cr 3. Only executes R script via \code{exec_r()} when no static file matches.
handleHttpGet.returns: Modifies `response` object in-place. No explicit return value.
handleHttpGet.title: handleHttpGet

run_http.description: Initializes HTTP server with specified port and web context directory, registers request handlers for different HTTP methods.
run_http.details: 1. Sets global configurations:\cr - \code{wwwroot}: File system handler for static content\cr - \code{deepseek}: Initialized Ollama AI context\cr - \code{apps}: URL routing rules from \code{scan_urls()}\cr 2. Attaches custom HTTP headers (X-Powered-By, Author, etc.)\cr 3. Registers handlers for GET/POST/PUT methods\cr 4. PUT method returns a test success message by default
run_http.examples: \donttest{ # Start server on port 8000 with default web root run_http(httpPort = 8000) }

parameters.name: webContext
parameters.text: (character) Path to web root directory. Default: "./wwwroot".

run_http.returns: Returns the HTTP socket object. Use \code{listen()} to start server.
run_http.title: run_http

.athena_ui.returns: (character) Full path to the package's web resources directory.
.athena_ui.title: .athena_ui

handleHttpPost.description: Processes incoming HTTP POST requests, routes to appropriate handler or executes R context script.
handleHttpPost.details: 1. Retrieves global configurations for web root directory (`wwwroot`) and registered apps (`apps`).\cr 2. When `verbose=TRUE`, prints debug information including raw HTTP headers.\cr 3. Routes request to app-specific handler if URL matches registered apps via \code{check_url()}.\cr 4. Falls back to executing R context script in `wwwroot` via \code{exec_r()} if no app matches.

parameters.name: req
parameters.text: An HTTP request object containing client data and headers.

parameters.name: response
parameters.text: An HTTP response object for building server output.

handleHttpPost.returns: Modifies `response` object in-place. No explicit return value.
handleHttpPost.title: handleHttpPost

init_ollama.description: Initializes and configures the Ollama AI client using global options. This function sets up the model and server connection, builds required tools, and returns the initialized client object for subsequent AI operations.
init_ollama.details: Uses `ollama_model` and `ollama_server` options from global environment to configure the client. Automatically attaches essential tools via `build_ollama_tools()` during initialization.
init_ollama.returns: Returns an initialized Ollama client object that's ready for AI operations. The returned object contains configured tools and settings.
init_ollama.title: init_ollama

ollama_talk.title: url handler for the LLMs Ai talk

build_ollama_tools.description: Scans the R environment to dynamically construct and attach AI tools to the Ollama client. Handles both system-defined tools and custom functions with Ollama-specific attributes. System tools take precedence to prevent naming conflicts with user-defined tools.
build_ollama_tools.details: The toolset construction process includes two phases: \enumerate{ \item System Tool Injection - Adds a mandatory `sys_info` tool containing: \itemize{ \item System name and introduction text \item Developer information \item Programming language details \item GitHub repository URL \item License information } \item Environment Scanning - Detects functions with \code{@ollama} attributes: \itemize{ \item Requires \code{roxygen2}-style documentation for parameters and descriptions \item Extracts argument specifications from \code{@param} tags \item Identifies required parameters through documentation analysis } }
build_ollama_tools.examples: \dontrun{ # Initialize client and build toolset client <- ollama::new_client() build_ollama_tools(client) # Check attached tools ollama::list_tools(client) }

parameters.name: deepseek
parameters.text: An Ollama client object to attach tools to. When NULL (default), uses the currently active client. Note that relying on implicit client selection is discouraged in production environments.

build_ollama_tools.returns: Invisibly returns the modified Ollama client object with attached tools.
build_ollama_tools.see_also: \code{\link{ollama::add_tool}} for the underlying tool attachment mechanism
build_ollama_tools.title: build_ollama_tools

file_proxy.details: The function performs three key operations: \enumerate{ \item Generates MD5 hash based on file path and current timestamp \item Creates nested temporary directory using hash fragments (e.g., /temp/a1b2c/d4e5f) \item Copies original file to hashed location while preserving extension }
file_proxy.examples: \dontrun{ # Set temporary directory first options(proxy_tmp = "/var/www/tmp") # Generate proxy link for sample file file_proxy("/data/files/report.pdf") # Returns: list( #   href = "/get/file?key=5d41402abc4b2a76b9719d911017c592", #   filename = "report.pdf" # ) }

parameters.name: file
parameters.text: A character string specifying the path to an existing local file. The file must exist and be accessible (will trigger error if not found).

file_proxy.returns: A named list containing download metadata with two elements: \describe{ \item{href}{Character string containing the URL path for file download, formatted as `/get/file?key=<md5_hash>`} \item{filename}{Character string preserving the original filename with extension} }
file_proxy.title: Generate a proxied download link for local files

router.description: Handles URL routing for web requests, mapping URLs to local R scripts or static files in the web context directory.
router.details: Routing logic:\cr - Root path (/) maps to index.html\cr - URLs ending with .R get direct script mapping\cr - Other URLs resolve to static files\cr Ensures proper extension handling for R script execution.

parameters.name: url
parameters.text: Parsed URL object from incoming request (should contain $path)

parameters.name: webContext
parameters.text: Base directory path for web resources

router.returns: Returns full filesystem path to either:\cr - Corresponding R script (appends .R if missing)\cr - Static file (defaults to index.html for root path)\cr
router.title: router

exec_r.description: Executes R scripts identified by the router and returns generated content through HTTP response.
exec_r.details: Operation flow:\cr 1. Resolve URL to local file path via router()\cr 2. If file exists, execute with source() and stream output\cr 3. Handle missing files with 404 error including normalized path\cr Ensures proper error handling and path disclosure prevention.

parameters.name: req
parameters.text: HTTP request object containing URL information

parameters.name: response
parameters.text: HTTP response object to write output to

exec_r.returns: Writes execution results to response object or returns HTTP error
exec_r.title: exec_r
